title: What's the most modern song considered classic rock? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is hard to answer because what is “considered Classic Rock” is not widely agreed-upon (see What is classic rock?). Most people think of the genre using the circular definition “it’s what my ‘Classic Rock’ radio station plays” but the term Classic Rock is not really hip any more and few stations define themselves that way. A lot of stations that are classic rock at their core also throw in more modern songs, blurring the lines further. Classic Rock radio began to diverge from just plain “rock radio” in the late ’70s as disco and punk started to splinter and divide the listeners into camps. See Around what time did classic rock stations first begin appearing, and what did they play? for more on how this happened. Once Classic Rock became a genre unto itself, only the occasional new stuff by groups (or solo acts from groups) already ensconced into the pantheon could enter, along with a few throwback groups whose popularity among classic rock fans could not be ignored. (Thus Don Henley’s “Dirty Laundry” and Van Halen’s “Hot For Teacher” from 1984 make it in, while R.E.M., The Replacements, and even Queensryche tracks from the same year don’t). The most recent songs you’ll find in the libraries of most Classic Rock stations are from the very early ‘90s, in the form of early Pearl Jam and Red Hot Chili Peppers tracks. The door to Classic Rock really slammed shut with the appearance of Nevermind and everything after that would be Alternative, Modern Rock, or something else. FiveThirtyEight did an exhaustive statistical analysis of what gets played on “Classic Rock” stations a couple of years ago, and this table tells part of the story:  Why Classic Rock Isn’t What It Used To Be To be pedantic, “most recent” doesn’t necessarily equate to “most modern”. The few acts that straddled Rock and New Wave probably qualify (U2 remains popular on classic rock stations, as do The Police and The Clash, and The Cars sneak in on some playlists). But given that The Lumineers and similar rootsy bands continually top the Alternative charts today, you might find that The Band and other acoustic artists are also pretty up-to-date. But if your station plays “Tomorrow Never Knows” by the Beatles (1966!), you probably can’t get more modern than that.

I would argue — strongly and forever — that The Wallflowers, in all their 50%-of-Bob-Dylan’s-DNA-meets-Bruce-Springsteen-stadium-rock grandeur, definitely counts as a Classic Rock act. They were called Alternative Rock in their heyday, but the genre was never an accurate fit; they’ve always sounded like they recorded the bulk of their catalogue 10 years earlier than they formed. Thus, “One Headlight” may well be the last popular Classic Rock song from the youngest big Classic Rock band. “Rebel, Sweetheart” may be the last great Classic Rock album. (As they formed in 1989, The Wallflowers are newer than other modern-ish Classic Rock acts — like Guns ’N Roses, which was formed in 1985). An alternate viewpoint is that U2’s probably put out something in the last 20 years which could count as the last great Classic Rock hit… “Vertigo”, perhaps? Matchbox Twenty often sounds more like a Classic Rock outfit than like anything else. More Than You Think You Are is an insanely great, beautifully knit-together album, and its feel is vastly more Classic Rock than it’s given credit for. Or maybe it’s a Train song (someone’s calling “Blasphemy!”, I’m sure, but I adore Train) — “Drops of Jupiter” has a classic church-rock vibe, and “I Got You” is so Classic Rock, it even absorbed some of the Doobie Brothers’ “Black Water”. Hell, Garth Brooks’ “8teen” sounds like a lost Bob Seger track, and it’s from 2016. I like to think this means Classic Rock will never truly die… The answer might even be Adele’s “Rolling in the Deep”. That’s a goddamn instant classic if I’ve ever heard one. Most Classic Rock DJs would likely disagree with almost everything I’ve said here — but, meh, what do they know, right? They’re mostly just paid to flog nostalgia. But if everything old is truly new again, and since I mentioned Bob Dylan roundaboutly: “Pay In Blood” is a bitchin’ modern Classic Rock song from 2012, absolutely one of the master’s very best. Stylistically, it belongs on any Classic Rock station worth its salt, and it also kicks the ass of most of what those stations are already playing. Maybe it’s the last great modern Classic Rock song, and maybe Tempest is the last great Classic Rock album. Again: I hope there will be many, many more. We need some depth and musicianship carried forward past the age of self-aggrandizing rap, hip-hop, and vacuous pop.
